abstract: The Chinese e-commerce giant, which analysts expect could be valued at $100 billion or more in an initial public offering, has made a proposal to allow top executives to retain control over corporate strategy, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.
snippet: The Chinese e-commerce giant, which analysts expect could be valued at $100 billion or more in an initial public offering, has made a proposal to allow top executives to retain control over corporate strategy, according to a person with knowledge ...
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant whose anticipated initial public offering is expected to be a blockbuster, has made a proposal to the Hong Kong stock exchange that would allow the company’s partners to nominate the majority of its board members, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Friday.

headline.main: Alibaba Said to Push to Allow Partners to Nominate Board Members
